title-group.article-title: Preclinical and clinical biomarker studies of CT1812: A novel approach to Alzheimer's disease modification

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Amyloid beta (AÎ²) oligomers are one of the most toxic structural forms of the AÎ² protein and are hypothesized to cause synaptotoxicity and memory failure as they build up in Alzheimer's disease (AD) patientsâ brain tissue. We previously demonstrated that antagonists of the sigmaâ2 receptor complex effectively block AÎ² oligomer toxicity. CT1812 is an orally bioavailable, brain penetrant small molecule antagonist of the sigmaâ2 receptor complex that appears safe and well tolerated in healthy elderly volunteers. We tested CT1812's effect on AÎ² oligomer pathobiology in preclinical AD models and evaluated CT1812's impact on cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) protein biomarkers in mild to moderate AD patients in a clinical trial (ClinicalTrials.gov NCT02907567).

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: Experiments were performed to measure the impact of CT1812 versus vehicle on AÎ² oligomer binding to synapses in vitro, to human AD patient post mortem brain tissue ex vivo, and in living APPSwe/PS1dE9 transgenic mice in vivo. Additional experiments were performed to measure the impact of CT1812 versus vehicle on AÎ² oligomerâinduced deficits in membrane trafficking rate, synapse number, and protein expression in mature hippocampal/cortical neurons in vitro. The impact of CT1812 on cognitive function was measured in transgenic Thy1 huAPPSwe/Lnd+ and wildâtype littermates. A multicenter, doubleâblind, placeboâcontrolled parallel group trial was performed to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and impact on protein biomarker expression of CT1812 or placebo given once daily for 28 days to AD patients (MiniâMental State Examination 18â26). CSF protein expression was measured by liquid chromatography with tandem mass spectrometry or enzymeâlinked immunosorbent assay in samples drawn prior to dosing (Day 0) and at end of dosing (Day 28) and compared within each patient and between pooled treated versus placeboâtreated dosing groups.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: CT1812 significantly and doseâdependently displaced AÎ² oligomers bound to synaptic receptors in three independent preclinical models of AD, facilitated oligomer clearance into the CSF, increased synaptic number and protein expression in neurons, and improved cognitive performance in transgenic mice. CT1812 significantly increased CSF concentrations of AÎ² oligomers in AD patient CSF, reduced concentrations of synaptic proteins and phosphorylated tau fragments, and reversed expression of many ADârelated proteins dysregulated in CSF.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: These preclinical studies demonstrate the novel diseaseâmodifying mechanism of action of CT1812 against AD and AÎ² oligomers. The clinical results are consistent with preclinical data and provide evidence of target engagement and impact on fundamental diseaseârelated signaling pathways in AD patients, supporting further development of CT1812.

p.mixed-citation: IzzoNJ, YuedeCM, LaBarberaKM, etÂ al. Preclinical and clinical biomarker studies of CT1812: A novel approach to Alzheimer's disease modification. Alzheimer's Dement. 2021;17:1365â1382. 10.1002/alz.12302 33559354

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Alzheimer's disease (AD) afflicts six million people in the United States, yet diseaseâmodifying therapies remain an unmet medical need. Investigational therapeutics are directed against a variety of potential targets,1 but the amyloid hypothesis remains a compelling rationale for AD drug development.2 More than 200 human mutations that cause earlyâonset familial AD have been identified, almost all conferring a single phenotype, increased amyloid beta (AÎ²) protein concentration or ratio.3, 4 The only protective mutation that both significantly lowers AD incidence and also exhibits strong functional evidence of protection, A673T (the Icelandic mutation), also impacts the AÎ² protein,5 resulting in significantly lowered binding affinity of AÎ² oligomers at synaptic receptors.6 Previous therapeutics have not effectively targeted AÎ² oligomers,7 one of the most toxic structural forms of the AÎ² protein.8 While monomeric AÎ² binds to many receptors, the oligomeric form of AÎ² has been shown to bind specifically and saturably to a single receptor site composed of LilRB2, Nogo receptor, and cellular prion proteins9, 10, 11 on neuronal synapses, where they induce changes consistent with a toxic diseaseârelated ligand. After oligomer binding, synaptic protein expression and the number of spines and synapses are reduced,12, 13, 14, 15, 16 synaptic plasticity processes (longâterm potential and depression) are disrupted,14, 17, 18, 19, 20, 21, 22, 23, 24, 25 and the process of new memory formation fails.2, 8, 10, 11, 26 Importantly, many preclinical studies suggest that after removal or reduction of the toxic oligomer species, synaptic protein expression, synapse number, and behavioral deficits can recover to normal levels.12, 27

Here, we report the discovery and continued development of drug candidate CT1812, a brain penetrant small molecule that targets AÎ² oligomers via a novel mechanism.26, 28 The first selective sigmaâ2 receptor antagonist to reach clinical trials,29 CT1812 is shown here to specifically displace AÎ² oligomers bound to neuronal receptors. The sigmaâ2 receptor complex plays a major role in cellular damage response mechanisms, with its constituent proteins regulating processes as diverse as autophagy, cholesterol synthesis and progesterone signaling, lipid membraneâbound protein trafficking, and receptor stabilization at the cell surface.30, 31, 32, 33, 34, 35, 36, 37 The sigmaâ2 receptor complex has previously been shown to be a key regulator of AÎ² oligomer receptors.26, 28 In the present study, we report evidence supporting a hypothesized mechanism of CT1812 action: when CT1812 binds specifically to the sigmaâ2 receptor ligand binding site and allosterically modulates the sigmaâ2 receptor complex, it causes destabilization of the neighboring AÎ² oligomer receptor binding sites, resulting in displacement of AÎ² oligomers from their receptors (in other words, an increase in their âoff rateâ). This lowers AÎ² oligomer affinity for synaptic receptors, mimicking the effect of the protective Icelandic mutation.6 This disruption of oligomer binding has previously been associated with an improvement in membrane trafficking, neuronal surface expression of synaptic proteins, prevention of spine loss, and improvement in cognitive deficits in animal models of AD.26, 28 The present study reports preclinical data demonstrating the novel mechanism of action of CT1812 in vitro and in vivo in an AD transgenic mouse model, and preliminary cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) biomarker data from the completed phase 1b/2a trial (NCT02907567), supporting its diseaseâmodifying mechanism in AD patients.29

CT1812 is an investigational therapeutic that has not been approved for any use by the US Food and Drug Administration. The riskâbenefit profile of CT1812 will be evaluated after adequate placeboâcontrolled clinical trials have been completed.

list-item.p: Systematic review: The authors engage in routine surveillance of relevant publications via PubMed and direct review of new issues of journals that publish research related to Alzheimer's disease (AD) or any mechanisms and research techniques used by the authors of this article. The articles are extensively referenced throughout.

Interpretation: These results are consistent with previously published preclinical evidence and demonstrate CT1812's target engagement and fundamental impact on diseaseârelated signaling pathways in patients with AD.
Future directions: These results support further development of CT1812, which is currently in multiple phase 2 trials in patients with AD.

sec.title: CT1812 displaces and prevents AÎ² oligomer binding
sec.p: Previously published studies that described unbiased proprietary library screening to identify compounds that block AÎ² oligomerâinduced toxicity of intracellular lipid membrane trafficking rates revealed compound potency correlated with sigmaâ2 receptor affinity.26, 28 Medicinal chemistry optimization resulted in the design of CT1812. CT1812 binds sigmaâ2 receptors with high affinity (FigureÂ 1A, KiÂ =Â 8.5Â nM), sigmaâ1 receptors with low affinity (KiÂ =Â 63Â nM), and is 100âfold selective for interacting with sigmaâ2 receptors versus 72 other drug targets (Cerep/Eurofins; Figure S1 in supporting information). CT1812 effectively prevented (EC50Â =Â 6.7 Î¼M) and reversed (EC50Â =Â 0.36 Î¼M) synthetic AÎ² oligomerâinduced membrane trafficking deficits in vitro in primary hippocampal/cortical cultures (21DIV, FigureÂ 1B) and prevented human AD patient brainâderived oligomerâinduced trafficking deficits (FigureÂ 1C). CT1812 prevented binding of AÎ² oligomers to synaptic receptor sites on neurons (AÎ² oligomer binding KdÂ =Â 0.43 Î¼M, plus CT1812Â =Â 1.12 Î¼M, FigureÂ 2A, B, D), and also displaced alreadyâbound AÎ² oligomers (AÎ² oligomer binding KdÂ =Â 0.61 Î¼M, plus CT1812Â =Â 1.16 Î¼M, FigureÂ 2C, E). CT1812 did not block the formation of AÎ² oligomers or disrupt their formation at concentrations up to 20Î¼M (Figure S2 in supporting information), suggesting that its ability to stop AÎ² oligomer binding and trafficking deficits results from CT1812 direct binding to sigmaâ2 receptors.

caption.p: CT1812 is a selective sigmaâ2 receptor ligand that prevents and treats amyloid beta (AÎ²) oligomerâinduced membrane trafficking deficits. A, CT1812 binds sigmaâ2 receptors with a 8.5Â nM Kd and sigmaâ1 receptors with a 63Â nM Kd as measured in radioligand displacement studies (nÂ =Â 2; means Â± standard deviation [SD]). B, Effects of synthetic AÎ² oligomers on vesicle trafficking in primary cultures of neurons and glia. Quantification is shown of the amount of formazan within intracellular vesicles in AÎ² oligomerâtreated (red dot) or vehicleâtreated (blue square) conditions, and the doseâdependent restoration of trafficking rate to normal vehicleâtreated values after CT1812 addition 1Â hour before addition of AÎ² oligomers (gray squares, EC50Â =Â 6.7 Î¼M, nÂ =Â 11 experiments) or 1Â hour after addition of AÎ² oligomers (black squares, EC50Â =Â 0.36 Î¼M, nÂ =Â 12 experiments). Vesicle trafficking was assayed 24Â hours after addition of AÎ² oligomers (1.75 Î¼M, total peptide; means Â± standard error of the mean). N represents the number of replicate experiments from separate cell culture preparations. C, Human Alzheimer's disease brain derived AÎ² oligomers (1âhour treatment) caused a 27 Â± 11% (SD; PÂ <Â 0.001, nÂ =Â 3) decrease in trafficking rate in cultured neurons and glia. Pretreatment of cultures for 1Â hour with 15 Î¼M CT1812 before addition of human derived AÎ² oligomers blocked the trafficking deficits (PÂ <Â 0.001 for AÎ² oligomers vs. AÎ² oligomers + CT1812, analysis of variance with Tukey's post hoc test, nÂ =Â 3 experiments). Each point represents results from quadruple replicates from AÎ² oligomer preparations isolated from three separate donor brains with the mean of all the points represented by the horizontal lines

CT1812 prevents amyloid beta (AÎ²) oligomer binding to and displaces bound oligomers from neuronal receptors, leading to restoration of synaptic density and protein expression in cultured mouse neurons. A, AÎ² oligomers (750Â nM,Â >Â 80% of Kd) bind specifically and saturably to a single receptor site on some, but not all, neurons in mature (>Â 21 DIV) primary hippocampal and cortical neuronal cultures. B, CT1812 [10 uM] prevents AÎ² binding by 59 Â± 8% (standard error of the mean [SEM]) when added 1Â hour prior to addition of AÎ² oligomers. C, CT1812 [10 uM] displaces AÎ² oligomer binding by 42 Â± 9% (SEM) when added 1Â hour after addition of AÎ² oligomers. Scale barÂ =Â 20 microns. D, CT1812 prevents binding and more than doubles the Kd of oligomer binding, from 430Â nM (at 0 Î¼M CT1812) to 1120Â nM (at 10 Î¼M CT1812; nÂ =Â 6; means Â± SEM). E, CT1812 displaces binding and nearly doubles the Kd of oligomer binding, from 610Â nM (at 0 Î¼M CT1812) to 1160Â nM (for 10 Î¼M CT1812; nÂ =Â 6; means Â± SEM). F, top, AÎ² oligomers bind to receptors at neuronal synapses (red, 6E10 immunodetection), resulting in a significant loss of synapses (green, drebrin immunodetection, 12.8 Â± 2.6% [SEM] decrease in synapse density, PÂ <Â 0.01Â vs. vehicleâtreated, Student t test [G]; the blue square represents synapse density in vehicleâtreated neurons). F, bottom,CT1812 displaces bound AÎ² oligomers and restores synaptic numbers to normal in a doseâdependent manner. Scale barÂ =Â 5 microns. G, CT1812 restores synapse number to normal whether added before (prevention, EC50Â =Â 68Â nM) or after (treatment, EC50Â =Â 127Â nM) AÎ² oligomers (*PÂ <Â 0.5Â vs. AÎ² oligomers alone for both conditions, Student's t test, means Â± SEM). Treatment with CT1812 restores synaptic protein expression in cultured rat neurons. H, Neurogranin is expressed at high levels in postsynaptic dendrites and synapses in a subset of neurons in primary hippocampal/cortical cultures. I, Addition of AÎ² oligomers (0.75 Î¼M, 24Â hours) causes a 28% loss of neurons expressing high levels of neurogranin (PÂ =Â 0.014). J, Treatment with 4.8 Î¼M CT1812 1 hour after addition of AÎ² oligomers restores the expression of neurogranin to normal levels (AÎ² oligomers vs. AÎ² oligomers + CT1812 PÂ =Â 0.031, vehicle vs. AÎ² oligomers + CT1812, n.s., analysis of variance [ANOVA] with Tukey's post hoc test, nÂ =Â 20). K, Synaptotagminâ1 is expressed in presynaptic terminals. L, Addition of AÎ² oligomers (3.5 Î¼M, 48Â hours) cause a 37% loss of synaptotagminâ1 presynaptic terminals in primary hippocampal/cortical cultures (PÂ =Â 0.0068, NÂ =Â 24). M, Treatment with 4.8 Î¼M CT1812 1 hour after addition of AÎ² oligomers blocks these losses and restores expression of synaptotagminâ1 levels (vehicle vs. AÎ² oligomers + CT1812, n.s). HâM, ANOVA with Tukey's post hoc test, nÂ =Â 20. For all cell culture experiments, n represents the number of replicate experiments from separate cell culture preparations, and data points represent means Â± SD or SEM as noted

sec.title: CT1812 restores diseaseârelated protein expression and synapse number in vitro
sec.p: AÎ² oligomers induce reversible spine retraction in vitro38 and cause a corresponding loss of synapses and synaptic proteins.13, 26 The effect of CT1812âinduced displacement of AÎ² oligomers on oligomerâinduced spine and synapse loss in cultured rat neurons was investigated using the cytoskeleton binding protein drebrin (expressed postsynaptically) as a marker of synapse number. Addition of AÎ² oligomers to neuronal cultures for 3Â hours caused a significant loss (mean Â± standard error of the mean 12.8% Â± 2.6%, PÂ <Â 0.01, twoâtailed Student's t test, FigureÂ 2F top, G) of drebrinâimmunoreactive synaptic puncta per neuron compared to vehicle treatment. This is similar to the degree of synapse loss seen using ultrastructural stereology methods in post mortem hippocampus from humans diagnosed with mild cognitive impairment.39 CT1812 prevented oligomerâinduced synapse loss in a doseâdependent manner (EC50Â =Â 68Â nM, PÂ <Â 0.05, paired, Student's t test of treated vs. vehicle, FigureÂ 2F bottom, G). Furthermore, addition of CT1812 to cultures 1Â hour after the addition of AÎ² oligomers resulted in a concentrationâdependent increase of synaptic number to normal levels (EC50Â =Â 127Â nM, FigureÂ 2G). Examination of synaptic protein expression corroborated these results. Neurogranin is expressed in dendrites and postsynaptic terminals (FigureÂ 2H), while synaptotagminâ1 is expressed in presynaptic terminals (FigureÂ 2K) of mature primary hippocampal/cortical neurons in vitro. AÎ² oligomer treatment led to a 28% loss of neurons expressing high levels of neurogranin (FigureÂ 2I) and a 37% loss of synaptotagminâ1 presynaptic terminals (FigureÂ 2L). Treatment with CT1812 blocked this loss and restored expression of both proteins to control levels (FigureÂ 2J, M). This suggests that CT1812âmediated displacement of AÎ² oligomers from neuronal synapses stops both downstream oligomerâinduced synaptic protein downregulation and synapse loss, facilitating synaptic recovery from toxic oligomer insult.

sec.title: CT1812 displaces AÎ² oligomers and facilitates clearance into CSF in vivo and in AD patient brain tissue
sec.p: To confirm the displacement of AÎ² oligomers from cells observed in vitro using an in vivo mouse model of AD, we adapted a novel microimmunoelectrode (MIE) technology previously used to detect rapid kinetic changes in total AÎ² concentration in brain interstitial fluid (ISF)40 (Figure S3AâE in supporting information). Using electrodes coated with the oligomerâspecific antibody A1141 placed in the hippocampus, AÎ² oligomers were measured in ISF of 12âmonthâold APPSwe/PS1dE9 transgenic mice.42 A single dose of CT1812 (0.3 Î¼M, or 3.0 Î¼M i.v.) resulted in a rapid and significant increase in AÎ² oligomer levels in hippocampal ISF relative to predose baseline (FigureÂ 3A, vertical dashed line, see Figure S3F). In contrast, no increase was observed in the ISF of vehicleâtreated transgenic mice. The rapid elevation of AÎ² oligomers after drug administration declined to baseline levels within the timeframe of the recording (120 minutes). In contrast, total AÎ² levels (primarily monomer) in the hippocampal ISF were not affected by the administration of CT1812 (FigureÂ 3B), thus CT1812 selectively reduces AÎ² oligomer extracellular concentrations without affecting AÎ² monomer levels.

caption.p: CT1812 treatment displaces amyloid beta (AÎ²) oligomers from mouse hippocampal receptors and post mortem Alzheimer's disease human patient tissue and facilitates their clearance into cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). A, B, Microimmunoelectrodes (MIE) coated with oligomerâspecific antibody A11 (A) or mAÎ²40 antibody HJ2 (B) in 12âmonthâold transgenic hAPP/PS1 mice detect soluble AÎ² in the hippocampal interstitial fluid (ISF). A, After intravenous injection of 0.3 or 3Â mg/kg CT1812 (vertical dashed line), soluble AÎ² oligomers are significantly elevated in hippocampal ISF in CT1812âtreated mice (nÂ =Â 7) compared to vehicleâtreated mice (nÂ =Â 4, means Â± standard error of the mean [SEM]; *** PÂ <Â 0.001, **** PÂ <Â 0.0001, twoâway analysis of variance [ANOVA] with Sidak's post hoc test for effect of drug vs. vehicle). B, CT1812 treatment does not cause a change in total AÎ² levels in the hippocampus (nÂ =Â 5) compared to vehicle treatment (nÂ =Â 4, means Â± SEM). CâE, AÎ² oligomers displaced from post mortem brain tissue sections from 8 AD patients were quantified by enzymeâlinked immunosorbent assay (ELISA; D) and native western blots (C [representative individual patient], E), and show the expected doseâdependent increase in concentration in CT1812âtreated compared to the vehicleâtreated condition. For western blots, the sum of the intensity of discrete AÎ² protein bands at 22, 33, 43, 48, and 85 Kd was quantified for each donor tissue section (C). In (D) and (E), values for AÎ² measured by ELISA for each brain tissue section and for intensity of western blot bands for each brain tissue section normalized to vehicleâtreated controls (dashed line) from the same donor are shown, with the mean of all the points represented by the horizontal lines (*PÂ <Â 0.05, ANOVA with Tukey's post hoc test for each treatment vs. vehicle treated controls). F (representative individual patient), G, H, AÎ² oligomers (red) located in a 2 Î¼M halo surrounding compact thioflavinâS positive plaques (green) are displaced from frozen post mortem human AD brain tissue sections (NÂ =Â 5 patients) by CT1812 in a doseâdependent manner normalized to vehicle treated brain sections (dashed line) from the same individual with the mean of all the points represented by the horizontal lines (*PÂ <Â 0.05, ANOVA with Tukey's post hoc test for each CT1812âtreated vs. vehicleâtreated controls). H, AÎ² intensity within plaques does not change. Scale barÂ =Â 20 Î¼M. I, J, Microimmunoelectrodes coated with oligomerâspecific antibody A11 (I) or panâAÎ² antibody HJ2 (J) in 12âmonthâold transgenic hAPP/PS1 mice detect soluble AÎ² in the lateral ventricle CSF. I, After intravenous injection of 0.3 (nÂ =Â 7) or 3 (nÂ =Â 5) mg/kg CT1812 (vertical dashed line), soluble AÎ² oligomers are significantly elevated in lateral ventricle CSF compared to vehicleâtreated mice (nÂ =Â 5, means Â± SEM). J, CT1812 treatment (nÂ =Â 5) did not cause a change in AÎ² monomer levels in the CSF compared to vehicle treatment (nÂ =Â 4 means Â± SEM). *** PÂ <Â 0.001, **** PÂ <Â 0.0001, twoâway ANOVA Sidak's post hoc test for effect of drug vs. vehicle

sec.p: To assess whether CT1812 displacement of AÎ² oligomers in AD model systems in vitro and in vivo may also occur in AD patients, we conducted ex vivo binding experiments in 10 Î¼Mâthick post mortem neocortical tissue sections obtained from patients with AD (Clinical Dementia Rating [CDR]Â =Â 3, nÂ =Â 8 patients, FigureÂ 3CâE). After incubation of adjacent sections in identical volumes containing increasing concentrations of CT1812 or vehicle, the supernate was removed and the levels of AÎ² displaced from the tissue sections quantified by enzymeâlinked immunosorbent assay (ELISA); the AÎ² remaining in the tissue sections was quantified via immunofluorescent microscopy. Analysis of the displaced material by ELISA for total AÎ² showed that ascending concentrations of CT1812 increased the amount of AÎ² released from the human brain tissue (FigureÂ 3D): nonâdenaturing western blots confirmed this material to be AÎ² oligomers (FigureÂ 3C, E, Figure S4 in supporting information). Additionally, CT1812 induced a concentrationâdependent decrease in AÎ² oligomer immunofluorescence intensity in the 2Â Î¼m region containing high concentrations of oligomers surrounding dense, thioflavinâS labeled plaque cores43, 44 (FigureÂ 3F, G) with similar but not statistically significant changes occurring within the plaque itself (FigureÂ 3H). These results demonstrate that CT1812 displaces prebound AÎ² oligomers from AD patient brain tissue.

Finally, the fate of AÎ² oligomers displaced by CT1812 was determined by placing the A11âcoated MIE in the lateral ventricle of transgenic APPSwe/PS1dE9 mice to measure AÎ² oligomers in the CSF. A significant, doseâdependent rise in AÎ² oligomer levels was detected in CSF after drug administration (FigureÂ 3I) and remained elevated for up to 2 hours, suggesting that displacement of AÎ² oligomers in the brain may lead to increased clearance into the CSF. In contrast, AÎ² monomer levels in the CSF were not affected by administration of CT1812 (FigureÂ 3J), indicating that CT1812 selectively facilitates clearance of oligomers, but not monomers, from the brain into the CSF.

sec.title: CT1812 improves cognitive performance in transgenic mice
sec.p: To assess whether this evidence of synapse preservation by CT1812 was associated with functional behavioral improvement, we evaluated changes in cognitive deficits in an aged transgenic mouse model of AD.26, 45, 46 Transgenic Thy1 huAPPSwe/Lnd+ male mice, aged 3.5 to 4.5 months, or wildâtype (WT) littermates, were administered vehicle or CT1812 10Â mg/kg once daily by oral gavage for 9 to 10Â weeks (nÂ =Â 12 for each group except for the transgenic CT1812âtreated group, which was nÂ =Â 13). Treatment of WT mice with CT1812 did not significantly alter motor behavior and did not change cognitive performance compared to that of WT vehicleâtreated animals. As expected, significant deficits in transgenic vehicleâtreated animals compared to WT vehicleâtreated animals were observed in the Activity Chamber test measuring exploration, the Y maze measuring spatial working memory, and the Fear Conditioning assays measuring aversive associative learning and memory. Significant improvements in spatial learning and memory were observed in transgenic animals treated with CT1812 compared to those treated with vehicle in the Water Maze (FigureÂ 4A), the YâMaze (FigureÂ 4B), and in contextual fear conditioning (FigureÂ 4C). In addition to improving spatial learning and memory, significant improvements were observed in hyperactivity as assessed via the Activity Chamber assay, and cueâdependent learning and memory as assessed in the Fear Conditioning assay. In WT mice, CT1812 had no effect on performance in any of the cognitive tests (FigureÂ 4AâC).

caption.p: Treatment with CT1812 improves learning and memory deficits in transgenic Alzheimer's mice. A, Transgenic Thyâ1 huAPPSwe/Ldn+ male mice treated with CT1812 (Tg + CT1812) learn the Morris water maze task significantly better than do transgenic vehicleâtreated mice (Tg + vehicle; PÂ =Â 0.016, twoâway repeated measures analysis of variance, Bonferroni post hoc *PÂ <Â 0.5; mean Â± standard error of the mean). CT1812 treatment does not affect nonâtransgenic animal performance (nTg + CT1812). B, Transgenic mice treated with CT1812 remember previous arms entered in the Y maze task significantly better (PÂ =Â 0.013, Student's t test) than chance (dashed line), but transgenic vehicleâtreated animals do not (nTg + vehicle, 62.7 Â± standard deviation [SD] 12.2%; Tg + vehicle, 56.1 Â± SD 9.2%; Tg + CT1812, 58.5 Â± SD 9.4%; nTg + CT1812, 65.3 Â± SD 6.0%). C, Transgenic mice show deficits in the Contextual Fear Conditioning test (PÂ =Â 0.037, Student's t test), while transgenic and nontransgenic mice treated with CT1812 do not (nTg + vehicle, 52.5 Â± SD 5.4%; Tg + vehicle, 37.9 Â± SD 6.4%; Tg + CT1812, 44.6 Â± SD 6.5%; nTg + CT1812, 50.9 Â± SD 5.1%). Each data point in (B) and (C) represents an individual mouse with the mean of all the points represented by the horizontal lines. D, Plasma and brain concentration of CT1812 after a single p.o. dose of 10Â mg/kg (nÂ =Â 3 mice per time point, mean Â± SD)

sec.p: Previous studies of eight other sigmaâ2 receptor antagonists closely related to CT1812 in Thy1 huAPPSwe/Lnd+ mice treated daily for 4Â weeks to 6 months indicated that behavioral improvements were observed as long as brain concentrations of drug were above a theoretical 80% receptor occupancy threshold concentration,26 but that plaque number and AÎ² monomer concentration (measured by ELISA) did not change. PK measurements of brain concentrations of CT1812 after treatment of Thy1 huAPPSwe/Lnd+ mice with 10Â mg/kg p.o. for 9 to 10Â weeks confirmed that this estimated 80% receptor occupancy level was achieved (FigureÂ 4D, brain concentration 24Â hours after last doseÂ =Â 19.9Â ng/mL, 84.4% receptor occupancy, greater than four times the sigmaâ2 receptor Ki value). Taken together, these studies indicate that threshold brain concentrations of CT1812 effectively improved cognitive deficits found in the huAPPSwe/Lnd+ mouse model of AD.

sec.title: Clinical biomarker evidence of CT1812âmediated synapse protection and disease modification
sec.p: After completion of firstâinâman clinical studies (NCT0257099729), CT1812 was advanced into clinical trials in AD patients. Mildâtoâmoderate AD patients with MiniâMental State Exam (MMSE) scores of 18 to 26 were randomized to receive one of three doses of CT1812 (90, 280, 560Â mg) or placebo once daily for 28 days (NÂ =Â 19, 4â5/group) in a doubleâblind phase 1b/2a clinical trial to determine safety and tolerability (trial COG0102, for full description, see clinicaltrials.gov NCT02907567). The randomized patients, 10 male and 9 female, had a mean age of 70.2 years (standard deviation [SD] 9.2) and body mass index of 24.75Â kg/m2 (SD 2.73). CSF concentrations at baseline and Day 28 confirmed no presence of CT1812 in the placebo group or at baseline in any dose group. Day 28 mean CSF concentrations of CT1812 rose in a doseâdependent manner (1.15Â ng/mL [SD 0.53] in the 90Â mg treatment group, 2.84Â ng/mL [SD 0.69] in the 280Â mg treatment group, and 4.96 [SD 8.49] in the 560Â mg treatment group). As expected in a study of limited treatment duration, change in exploratory measures of cognitive function from baseline was similar in CT1812âtreated and placebo groups. CSF samples collected from each patient at baseline and at the end of study were used for protein measurements using targeted (i.e., ELISA, western blot, liquid chromatography with tandem mass spectrometry [LCâMS/MS) and nontargeted (i.e., unbiased LCâMS/MS proteomics) methods; missing samples and variable sample volumes reduced the number of matched baseline and day 28 patient CSF samples available for subsequent analysis.

Protein gel electrophoresis (western blot) was used to measure AÎ² oligomer concentration in CSF samples from each patient taken at Day 0 and 28 and percent change for each patient was calculated. Due to the small number of AD patients in each dosing group, CT1812 dose groups were pooled for comparisons to placebo. After 28 days of treatment, CSF AÎ² oligomer concentration (nÂ =Â 3) in placeboâtreated patients trended lower from levels at their own baseline, while levels in CT1812âtreated patients (nÂ =Â 10) increased significantly compared to placeboâtreated patients (FigureÂ 5A and Figure S5 in supporting information). This finding is consistent with preclinical studies indicating that CT1812 displaces and clears toxic AÎ² oligomers from the brain into CSF (FigureÂ 3I) and provides supporting evidence of clinical target engagement. In contrast, AÎ²40 and 42 monomer levels measured with ELISA were not different between Day 0 and Day 28, or between treatment groups in this trial (Figure S5B, C).

caption.p: CT1812 treatment significantly impacts cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) biomarkers of target engagement and diseaseârelated biology. Protein concentrations in CSF samples from Alzheimer's disease (AD) patients in a 28âday phase 1b/2a clinical trial of CT1812 vs. placebo were measured via enzymeâlinked immunosorbent assay (ELISA), liquid chromatography tandem mass spectrometry (LCâMS/MS), or gel electrophoresis. A, After 28 days the concentration of amyloid beta (AÎ²) oligomers measured via western blot in CT1812âtreated AD patient CSF increases compared to the patient's own baseline and vs. placebo (PÂ =Â 0.014, Student's t test, nÂ =Â 3 placebo, 10 CT1812âtreated), providing supporting evidence of clinical target engagement. At day 28 of the study, the concentration of synaptic damage proteins neurogranin (B, measured by ELISA) and synaptotagminâ1 (C, measured by LCâMS/MS) decreases compared to the patient's own baseline and vs. placebo (PÂ =Â 0.050 analysis of covariance, nÂ =Â 5 placebo, 11 CT1812âtreated; and F1,12Â =Â 8.8, PÂ =Â 0.011, nÂ =Â 4 placebo, 9 CT1812âtreated, respectively) providing evidence of a positive effect on synapses in patients with AD. A, B, and C, Data from individual patients are displayed with the treatment group mean represented by the horizontal lines. These changes are corroborated (D) by significant expression changes (PÂ <Â 0.05) in multiple synaptic proteome proteins in the CSF measured by unbiased LCâMS/MS in AD patients treated for 28 days with CT1812 vs. placebo. E, CSF proteomics identifies a subset of proteins significantly altered with CT1812 that have been reported to be significantly regulated in AD.92 Data are expressed as mean % change in protein concentration in CSF from CT1812 treated (nÂ =Â 11) vs. placebo (nÂ =Â 4; blue) and AD vs. control to illustrate how these proteins are altered in AD relative to cognitively normal ageâmatched controls. All analytes shown are significantly regulated (PÂ <Â 0.05) in AD patients vs. control53 and in the present study. F, After 28 days of treatment, the abundance of six tau phosphorylation peptides decreased by 30% (the threshold for noise distribution), or more after treatment with CT1812 compared to placebo (T52, T205, S262, S263, S285, S305) while one site increased more than 30% (S191), but the concentration of unphosphorylated tau did not change, providing evidence of CT1812 impact on pathological disease signaling. Colored bars represent amino acid sites within tau that are phosphorylated by GSK3Î² with priming (blue bars) or without priming (green bars)93, 94

sec.p: The concentrations of several synaptic and axonal proteins are elevated in CSF of AD patients compared to ageâmatched cognitively normal individuals as a result of central nervous system synaptic damage due to the disease;47, 48, 49, 50, 51 some markers exhibit greater sensitivity to diseaseârelated changes than do others. We measured concentrations of synaptic and axonal proteins in CSF samples from AD patients in trial COG0102 using ELISA (neurogranin and neurofilament light [NfL]) or targeted LCâMS/MS (synaptotagminâ1, SNAPâ25). At 28 days, CSF concentrations of neurogranin and SYTâ1 decreased in CT1812âtreated AD patients relative to placeboâtreated AD patients CSF (FigureÂ 5B, neurogranin, nÂ =Â 5 placebo, 11 treated; PÂ =Â 0.050 analysis of covariance; FigureÂ 5C, synaptotagminâ1, nÂ =Â 4 placebo, 9 treated; F1,12Â =Â 8.8, PÂ =Â 0.011, linear mixed model), consistent with preclinical evidence of CT1812âmediated facilitation of synaptic recovery from insult with toxic AÎ² oligomers. CSF concentrations of NfL and SNAPâ25 did not change to a significant degree in CT1812âtreated AD patients versus placebo (Figure S5D, G).

Data from unbiased LCâMS/MS proteomics measurements of CSF were evaluated for effects on synaptic proteins (FigureÂ 5D). Of the 3160 proteins detected in the CSF of this patient cohort, the abundance of 315 proteins was significantly different between CT1812â and placeboâtreated patients (analysis of variance [ANOVA] followed by Fisher's least significant difference [LSD]; PÂ <Â 0.05). Pathway analysis using three independent bioinformatics platforms (IPA Canonical Pathway [v51963813], Metacore [v19.4 build 69900], STRING [v11]) indicates that CT1812 significantly (PÂ <Â 0.05) impacts synapticârelated pathways including NâmethylâDâaspartate receptor trafficking, glycogen kinase synthase kinaseâ3Î² (GSK3Î²), and Wnt signaling, as well as cytoskeletal reorganization. Given the loss of synapses in AD patients along with the preclinical evidence that CT1812 rescues synapse number, we queried which proteins in the synaptic proteome52 were altered by CT1812 treatment. Twentyâfive proteins in the synaptic proteome52 were identified to be differentially expressed (ANOVA followed by Fisher's LSD; PÂ <Â 0.05) in CT1812â compared to placeboâtreated patient CSF. To understand the functions of these proteins with respect to specific synaptic function in more detail, network analysis was performed. The highest scoring network, Cell Morphology, Cellular Assembly and Organization, Cellular Development, comprised 14 out of 25 of the synaptic proteins, a significantly greater number than expected by random chance (Figure S6A in supporting information, IPA ScoreÂ =Â 26; PÂ <Â 1Â ÃÂ 10â25). This indicates that these proteins may play a role in dendritic branching, cytoskeletal remodeling, and neurotransmission (Figure S6B). This provides evidence supporting CT1812's positive effect on synapses in patients with AD.

Out of 520 CSF proteins significantly altered in AD patients versus ageâmatched controls (PÂ <Â 0.05) in a recent study,53 334 were detected in the COG0102 CSF proteomics dataset. Of those 334 proteins, a subset of 20 moved in the opposite direction (i.e., reversed ADârelated changes) and were also significantly different in CT1812âtreated compared to placebo (FigureÂ 5E). Several of these proteins are involved in key biological pathways known to be disrupted in AD, including cholesterol transport (apolipoprotein A2 [APOA2]), oxidative stress (ceruloplasmin [CP]), complement (complement C1r subcomponentâlike protein [C1RL]), and synaptic transmission (14â3â3 protein beta/alpha [YWHAZ]). This provides supporting evidence for a broad improvement of diseaseârelated signaling by CT1812 in patients with AD.

One of the hallmarks of AD is hyperphosphorylated tau protein, which comprises neurofibrillary tangles (NFTs).54, 55, 56, 57, 58 We evaluated AD patient CSF for concentrations of unphosphorylated and phosphorylated tau protein fragments taken at baseline and after 28 days of CT1812 or placebo treatment via LCâMS/MS (FigureÂ 5F); phosphorylated peptide fragments representing 33 distinct phosphorylation sites on tau were detected. The abundance of six phosphorylation sites decreased by 30% or more (FigureÂ 5F)59, 60 after treatment with CT1812 compared to placebo while one site increased more than 30% (the threshold for noise distribution61), but the concentration of unphosphorylated tau did not change. In agreement with these results, ELISA measurements of the change from baseline of phospho tau (pâtau) (181) and total tau (tâtau) was similar in CT1812âtreated and placebo groups (Figure S5E, F). Additionally, LCâMS/MS measurements of concentrations of kinases that phosphorylate tau, such as GSK3Î², trended lower by 25% in CT1812âtreated patients (not significantly different from placeboâtreated patients, PÂ =Â 0.098). These results suggest that CT1812 may act upstream of tau kinases to reduce their concentration and resulting activity, while having no impact on tau expression or regulation. To identify phosphorylation sites within tau that might covary in abundance in response to CT1812 treatment, correlation analyses were performed and a heatmap was generated. The abundance of 21 pairs of pâtau sites was found to be significantly correlated with one another (Figure S7 in supporting information), supporting the hypothesis that CT1812 may act upstream of tau kinases/phosphatase to impact tau phosphorylation at specific amino acid sites. Taken together, these clinical biomarker data support a potential therapeutic impact of CT1812 in patients with AD.

sec.title: CT1812 displaces AÎ² oligomers in several preclinical models of AD
sec.p: The AÎ² oligomer hypothesis remains a compelling rationale for AD drug development programs.2 Supporting evidence for this comes from the genetic determinants of autosomal dominant AD and AD complicating Down syndrome,62 the protective effect of the Icelandic mutation of the amyloid precursor protein5, 6 animal data indicating the toxic effects of AÎ² oligomer species on synaptic function8, 63 and its reversibility,27 and the observation that AÎ² accumulation alone in cognitively and clinically normal individuals predicts symptomatic AD with high likelihood.64 Drug development programs targeting AÎ² include active and passive AÎ² immunotherapeutics7 and secretase inhibitors that decrease AÎ² peptide generation,65 but none effectively or selectively target AÎ² oligomers.

The current study demonstrates that CT1812 displaces AÎ² oligomers from neurons with three independent approaches: in vitro cell culture, in vivo rodent studies (including two different mouse models of AD), and ex vivo human brain CSF and tissue. In cultured rat brain cells in vitro, CT1812 shifted the binding of exogenously applied, synthetic AÎ² oligomers to lower affinity whether added before or after oligomers. Importantly, CT1812âmediated reduction of oligomer affinity phenocopies or mimics the effect of the AD's protective Icelandic mutation on oligomer affinity,6 and is the only drug candidate currently in development reported to do so. This is significant because drug candidates with the same mechanism as protective variants are expected to have a higher success rate in the clinic.66 CT1812 treatment for 1Â hour did not decrease the intensity of preâbound AÎ² oligomers as completely as it did when added to cultures prior to the oligomers. It is possible that longer treatment with CT1812 can achieve a greater level of displacement. However, incubation with AÎ² oligomers for longer times results in internalization of a portion of the AÎ² oligomer labeling,26 complicating quantification of the compound treatment. Nonetheless, our results demonstrate that CT1812 both displaces alreadyâbound AÎ² oligomers and prevents the binding of AÎ² oligomers to neuronal synaptic receptors; displaced oligomers will not reâbind as long as CT1812 remains present. Thus, CT1812 will likely continue to exert its effect as concentrations of oligomers rise throughout the course of AD. In separate biochemical assays using an oligomerâspecific ELISA, CT1812 does not interact directly with oligomers and did not disrupt preformed oligomers or block oligomer formation (Figure S2). In post mortem human AD brain tissue sections, CT1812 caused a concentrationâdependent increase in AÎ² displaced from the tissue as measured by AÎ² ELISA, as well as a concentrationâdependent increase in several oligomeric species of AÎ² as detected by western blot analysis of the material displaced from the tissue.67 This was accompanied by a decrease in AÎ² within the tissue section in the 2 micron oligomerâenriched halo surrounding plaques. While we cannot rule out compoundâmediated displacement of oligomers from extrasynaptic sites that are below the level of detection of our imaging methods, oligomers that are doseâdependently displaced by CT1812 are highly likely to originate from synaptic receptor sites; because oligomers are waterâsoluble, oligomers in the interstitial fluid in these frozen tissue sections should freely diffuse in any aqueous media and be detectable in the vehicle treated condition as well (FigureÂ 3CâE). The transgenic mouse MIE measurements provide additional insight on the selectivity of CT1812's effect on oligomers: a single dose of CT1812 rapidly increased concentrations of AÎ² oligomer, but not AÎ² monomer in the brain. Together, these results demonstrate that CT1812 is a doseâdependent, negative allosteric modulator of AÎ² oligomer binding.

Unexpectedly, these same measurements provided evidence suggesting that CT1812 directly or indirectly facilitates clearance of AÎ² oligomer, but not monomer, out of the brain and into the CSF; it rapidly increases ISF and CSF concentrations of oligomers in a doseâdependent manner, but not monomers. The difference in kinetic rate of increase in AÎ² oligomer concentration between the hippocampus and lateral ventricle may result from different electrode sampling volumes due to diffusion constraints within brain tissue compared to CSF. The basis for this selective clearance of AÎ² oligomers but not monomers is currently unclear. While mechanisms of AÎ² monomer clearance from the brain into CSF have been studied extensively (reviewed in Yuede etÂ al.40), oligomer clearance mechanisms are currently unknown. One possible mechanism is suggested by recent studies demonstrating direct interactions of sigmaâ2 receptor complex component proteins PGRMC1 and TMEM97 with lowâdensity lipoprotein (LDL) receptor, required for ligandâbound LDL receptor internalization,31 and sigmaâ2 receptorâmediated cellular uptake of AÎ² via interactions with apolipoprotein E and the LDL receptor.31, 68 Previously tested closely related sigmaâ2 receptor antagonists do not impact monomer or fibril levels in Thy1 huAPPSwe/Lnd+ transgenic mice after chronic shortâterm administration.26 To more fully explore the role of these proteins in AD, future studies (including studies in AD mouse models crossâbred with conditional tissueâspecific knockouts of each protein to avoid lethality) are required.

We hypothesize that displacement of toxic AÎ² oligomers from synaptic receptor sites and clearance of oligomer into the CSF underlies the improvement of cognitive performance in transgenic AD mice seen with chronic CT1812 administration. As with other closely related sigmaâ2 receptor antagonists,26 CT1812 improves transgenic mouse behavior at brain concentrations corresponding to an estimated 80% receptor occupancy; typical for an antagonist mechanism of action, threshold concentrations of drug are required to block effects. While CT1812's in vitro assay EC50 values range from high nanomolar to low micromolar concentrations, behavioral improvement is observed at brain concentrations closer to CT1812's Ki at sigmaâ2 receptors (8.5Â nM). The basis for this difference is unclear but may be due to the short duration and high concentrations of synthetic AÎ² oligomers used in the in vitro assays. Once displaced from synaptic receptors, the oligomers are no longer able to harm synapses and are subject to elimination through yet to be defined clearance pathways.

sec.title: Preliminary biomarker evidence for CT1812 target engagement and diseaseâmodification in patients with AD
sec.p: Protein measurements of CSF samples from the 28âday clinical trial COG0102 provide preliminary evidence of target engagement and potential impact on disease in mildâtoâmoderate AD patients consistent with preclinical data. CSF concentrations of AÎ² oligomers increase in CT1812âtreated patients versus placebo similar to preclinical studies, indicating that CT1812 displaces and clears toxic AÎ² oligomer from the brain into CSF. CSF concentrations of the postsynaptic dendritic protein neurogranin, typically significantly elevated in AD patients,51, 69, 70, 71 are reduced by CT1812 treatment, compared to changes in placebo patients. Additionally, several synaptic proteins are significantly different in CT1812â versus placeboâtreated patients; bioinformatics analysis of these changes support preclinical evidence of a positive impact of CT1812 on synaptic pathways.

Analysis of CSF concentrations of phosphorylated tau fragments in AD patients revealed that treatment with CT1812 induced a broad reduction in tau phosphorylation at multiple amino acid sites without affecting unphosphorylated tau concentration. Many of the residues altered by CT1812 treatment have been previously implicated in ADârelated changes.72, 73, 74, 75, 76, 77 Data correlating phosphorylation at any given amino acid of tau with disease progression in patients (as well as how closely mouse disease models reflect such changes) are still emerging.

Preclinical evidence demonstrates that AÎ² oligomer binding results in upregulation of tau kinase activity2 leading to tau phosphorylation at multiple sites. The observed reduction in GSK3Î² as well as tau phosphorylation in CT1812âtreated patients provides the first clinical biomarker evidence supporting the AÎ² oligomer hypothesis of AD and further support of CT1812's diseaseâmodifying mechanism of action.

We hypothesize that changes in CSF concentration of a subset of proteins with CT1812 treatment reflect target engagement in the brain. Further clinical studies with longer treatment duration are underway; treatmentârelated impact on biomarkers in these independent clinical cohorts will provide additional insight on CT1812 target engagement and AD pathobiology as well as insight into how covariates like sex, age, and apolipoprotein E status impact response to drug. The effects of these changes in CSF protein concentrations on cognition and health is unknown and the relative benefit of these effects compared to the risks of the drug are being determined in ongoing and future placeboâcontrolled clinical trials.

sec.title: CT1812 for the treatment of AD
sec.p: The hypothesized diseaseâmodifying mechanism of action of CT1812 is illustrated in FigureÂ 6. In the normal brain (FigureÂ 6A), the sigmaâ2 receptor complex regulates the plasma membrane surface expression of putative AÎ² oligomer receptor complex component proteins LilRB2, Nogo receptor, and cellular prion protein as well as several other receptors78 (FigureÂ 6B). In AD, AÎ² oligomers bind to their receptor, altering its function and/or protein interactions, and resulting in a compensatory upregulation of the sigmaâ2 receptor complex (FigureÂ 6C).79, 80 The binding of AÎ² oligomers then leads to synaptic damage and release of presynaptic and postsynaptic proteins such as neurogranin and synaptotagminâ1 into the ISF and CSF (FigureÂ 6D). CT1812 binds to and allosterically modulates the sigmaâ2 receptor (FigureÂ 6E), causing destabilization of the neighboring AÎ² oligomer receptor binding sites with resultant displacement of AÎ² oligomers from synaptic receptors (i.e., increase in the âoff rateâ) without affecting normal synaptic protein function. CT1812 is thus a negative allosteric modulator of AÎ² oligomer binding to synaptic receptors. As a result of the removal of toxic oligomers, synapse number and memory are restored to normal (FigureÂ 6F). CT1812 selectively displaces AÎ² oligomers shortly after entering the brain and prevents them from rebinding as long as brain drug levels remain above an estimated 80% receptor occupancy.26 Chronic administration provides sustained protection from the synaptotoxic oligomer assault, facilitating synaptic recovery.

caption.p: Hypothesized mechanism of action of CT1812: synaptoprotective displacement of toxic amyloid beta (AÎ²) oligomers from neurons. A, In the absence of AÎ² oligomers, preâ and postâsynaptic proteins such as synaptotagminâ1 and neurogranin are expressed at normal levels. B, The sigmaâ2 receptor complex tightly regulates the oligomer receptor complex by stabilizing plasma membrane expression of oligomer receptor component proteins. C, Oligomer binding results in changing expression/localization of synapse associated proteins, spine loss, and memory failure, as well as upregulation of the sigmaâ2 receptor complex. D, Fragmented preâ and postâsynaptic proteins such as synaptotagminâ1 and neurogranin move into interstitial fluid and then cerebrospinal fluid. E, CT1812 binds to the sigmaâ2 receptor ligand binding site within the sigmaâ2 receptor complex, acting as a negative allosteric modulator of AÎ² oligomer binding. This destabilizes the oligomer binding site and displaces oligomers from synapses without affecting normal synapse protein function. F, Synapse number and memory are restored to normal levels

sec.p: The current studies suggest that CT1812 effectively and selectively targets AÎ² oligomers by a novel mechanism of action not previously demonstrated for any other therapeutics currently in development. CT1812 is both the first selective sigmaâ2 receptor antagonist to be used in clinical trials, and the first therapeutic demonstrated to displace toxic AÎ² oligomers from synaptic receptor sites and selectively facilitate their clearance into the CSF. Displacement of oligomers lowers their binding affinity (KD) to synaptic receptors significantly, thus CT1812 is the only therapeutic currently in development that mimics the effect of the protective Icelandic A673T mutation.6 This mechanism is significant, as therapeutics that recapitulate the effects of protective mutations have a track record of clinical success.66

Currently, approved AD medications do not stop the disease course, but simply treat symptoms for a limited time. These preclinical results of CT1812 in rodent models of AD demonstrate that CT1812 blocks AÎ² oligomer binding to neurons, reduces synapse loss, restores synaptic protein expression, facilitates oligomer clearance into the CSF, and restores cognitive function. The ability of CT1812 to improve cognitive performance in transgenic mice while not affecting the performance of WT mice supports a specific effect of CT1812 on the pathological pathway of AD: this diseaseâselective mechanism may provide an advantage over other therapeutic approaches that impact brain function more widely.

Preliminary evidence from the phase 1b/2a clinical trial reported here supports these findings. This study was limited by small patient numbers and short duration of treatment in the COG0102 trial. Larger studies with additional dose levels will be required to establish doseâresponse relationships with biomarker changes, and distinguish both acute and longâterm diseaseâmodifying effects of CT1812 treatment. While not all proteins and signaling pathways known to be dysregulated in AD were affected by treatment with CT1812, several pathways were significantly impacted (including cholesterol transport, oxidative stress, complement, and synaptic transmission; FigureÂ 5E). Together, these results provide encouraging evidence of the impact of CT1812 on multiple aspects of disease in AD patients and support further development of this drug candidate so that the relative benefit and risks of CT1812 can be more thoroughly evaluated.

CT1812 is currently being studied in four randomized, doubleâblind, placeboâcontrolled phase 2 studies (6 monthsâ1 year in treatment duration) in patients with mild to moderate AD: SNAP (NCT03522129), SPARC (NCT03493282), SHINE (NCT03507790), and SEQUEL. An additional 18âmonth study in 540 early AD patients (MMSE 20â30) is being planned in collaboration with the ACTC clinical trial network. The safety and tolerability of CT1812 will continue to be explored in all clinical trials.

sec.title: Radioligand binding
sec.p: Radioligand competition assays to determine affinity for sigmaâ2 and sigmaâ1 receptors were performed at Eurofins Cerep SA (Le Bois L'Ã©vÃªque, France) in membranes from Jurkat cells (immortalized human T cells). Assays for sigmaâ2 receptors used 25Â nM [3H]1,3âdi(2âtolyl) guanidine in the presence of 1 Î¼M (+)âpentazocine while assays for sigmaâ1 receptors used 15Â nM [3H](+)âpentazocine. Nonâspecific binding in both assays was defined in the presence of 10 Î¼M haloperidol.81 Estimated percent receptor occupancy for in vivo behavioral studies (see below) was calculated according to the formula 100*(concentration/Ki)/([concentration/Ki] + 1), where Ki is determined by radioligand competition binding (CT1812Â =Â 8.5Â nM).26

sec.title: Neuronal cultures
sec.p: Mixed neuronal and glia cultures were made from embryonic day 18 (E18) Sprague Dawley rat brains and grown in polyâD Lysine coated plates for 21 days, as previously described.26, 28 All procedures were approved by the Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee at Cognition Therapeutics and were in compliance with the Office of Laboratory Animals Welfare and the Guide for the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals, Eighth Edition. Embryos from a single rat were pooled to produce a unique dissociated neuronal culture. All analyses described below were performed on at least three unique cultures. Healthy cultures typically contain 20% to 35% MAP2âpositive neurons. CT1812 was tested in quadruplicate wells for each concentration in at least three replicate experiments with data from all experiments pooled for analysis with means Â± standard deviation (SD) or standard error of the mean (SEM) as noted.

sec.title: AÎ²Â oligomer preparation
sec.p: Synthetic human AÎ²1â42 peptide was prepared as previously described.26, 28 Briefly, peptide was treated according to published methods to remove any structural assemblies.82, 83 An AÎ² monomer film was prepared, dissolved, diluted to 100 Î¼M, and incubated at 4Â°C to form oligomers. The resulting preparations were centrifuged to remove any insoluble fibrils, and the supernate added to cultures. All studies using synthetic oligomers were performed with this preparation unless otherwise specified. All lots of AÎ²1â42 are put through a strict quality control processes, described previously,26, 28 before use in experiments. As previously reported, oligomers produced via this method typically range from 25â275Â kDa when measured via nonâdenatured western blots (FigureÂ 2, 26).

Human AD patientâ (Braak V/VI) and ageâmatched control hippocampal brain specimens, less than 24Â hours post mortem, were obtained from the Brown Brain Bank following previously described procedures.26, 28 Tissue was prepared as previously described.26, 28 Briefly, the brain tissue was homogenized and centrifuged, supernate were immunoâdepleted and concentrated to obtain the 10â100Â kDa sizeâfractionated oligomers, which were then captured on 6E10âconjugated agarose columns (Pierce). The released material was desalted and stored at â80Â°C. Use of post mortem brain specimens met the exemption criteria for Department of Health and Human Services regulations, as previously explained.26, 28

sec.title: In vitro trafficking assay
sec.p: Vesicular trafficking was measured using an adaptation of a method as previously described.26, 84 Neurons were treated with compounds and/or AÎ² oligomer preparations (0.086% DMSO in culture media) and incubated for 1 to 24Â hours at 37Â°C in 5% CO2. For prevention studies, CT1812 was added at indicated concentrations 1Â hour prior to addition of AÎ² oligomers. In treatment studies, AÎ² oligomers were added 1Â hour prior to addition of CT1812. Tetrazolium salts (3â[4,5âdimethylthiazolâ2yl]â2,5diphenyl tetrazolium bromide, Roche Molecular Biochemicals) were added at a final concentration of 0.75Â mM and incubated at 37Â°C for 60 to 90Â minutes. Vesicular formazan remaining in cells was quantified by absorbance spectrometry (590Â nm with 690Â nm subtracted) after extraction with 1.6% Tweenâ20. All compounds were tested in quadruplicate wells for each concentration in at least eight replicate experiments with data from all experiments pooled for analysis with means Â± SEM.

sec.title: In vitro AÎ² binding assay
sec.p: Assessment of AÎ² oligomer binding was performed as previously described.26, 28 Briefly, cultures were either (for prevention studies) treated with CT1812 for 30 minutes, followed by synthetic AÎ²1â42 oligomer preparation for 60Â minutes, or (for displacement studies) treated with oligomers 30Â minutes prior to the addition of CT1812. Cells were then fixed and labeled for immunofluorescent microscopy as previously described.26 All data for AÎ² binding presented represents total fluorescent intensity of AÎ² label in neurite spots per neuron in relative fluorescent units (RFUs). Replications and statistical procedures for the quantification of AÎ² immunofluorescent intensity were previously described.26

sec.title: In vitro synapse counting assay
sec.p: Synapse number was quantified using quantitative immunofluorescent microscopy of drebrinâlabeled puncta (Millipore ABâ10140) along MAP2âpositive neurites (Millipore AB5543) as previously described.26 Additional immunofluorescent labeling was performed on neuronal cultures for SYTâ1 (Synaptic Systems #105 103) and for neurogranin (Abcam ab23570).

sec.title: Human tissue ex vivo AÎ² displacement
sec.p: Displacement of AÎ² from human tissue was assessed as previously described.28 Briefly, brains from human AD patients were obtained through the Massachusetts Alzheimer's Disease Research Center and Massachusetts General Hospital (MGH) Neuropathology Department. Experiments using human brain were reviewed and approved by the Academic and Clinical Central Office for Research and Development medical research ethics committee, a joint office of the University of Edinburgh and National Health Service (NHS) Lothian (approval 15âHVâ016). Parahippocampal gyrus sections (one section per specimen per condition) were incubated with 0.1, 1.0, 10, or 15 Î¼M CT1812 in phosphateâbuffered saline (PBS), or vehicle for 60Â minutes as previously described26 and then labeled with an antibody specific to AÎ² (AWâ7, gift from Dominic Walsh85). Dense core amyloid plaques and NFTs were labeled with 0.05% ThioflavinâS (Sigma Aldrich) in 50% ethanol for 8Â minutes before treatment with 80% ethanol for 30 seconds. Images were analyzed in ImageJ86 using a custom macro (described in figure S4 in Izzo etÂ al.28). A total of 105 to 279 plaques were analyzed for each treatment from eight different donors and average intensities for each specimen were calculated. The median intensity value was calculated for each specimen and subjected to multivariate correlation analysis as previously described.28 Determination of total AÎ² concentration eluted from human donor brain tissue was performed using a high sensitivity, human Beta Amyloid (1â42) ELISA Kit (Wako, cat # 296â64401) which uses BAN50/BC05 (Fab').

sec.title: Western blot analysis of AÎ² oligomers
sec.p: Nonâdenaturing western blot conditions were used to avoid the generation of AÎ² assembly and disassembly artifacts, as previously described.26 Briefly, baseline and end of study CSF samples from AD patients participating in clinical trial COG0102 were collected in polypropylene tubes in 500 Î¼L and frozen at â80Â°C until analysis. Upon receipt, the samples were thawed and quickly aliquoted into polypropylene tubes coated with isotonic human serum albumin and refrozen until analysis by native western gels. Because the effects of blood on AÎ² oligomer formation in CSF is unknown, an aliquot of each patient sample was preâanalyzed on a western blot using luminol and horseradish peroxide to test for the presence of heme. Final western gel analysis was performed on samples excluding those containing hemolyzed blood. Samples were run on TrisâHCl nondenaturing gels, transferred to nitrocellulose, and probed with 82E1 mouse monoclonal AÎ² antibody (IBL America) and visualized by chemiluminescence after detection using a goat anti mouse IgGâhorseradish peroxidase secondary antibody (Millipore). All reagents were filtered through 0.1 micron filters to eliminate background debris. Band intensities on the gels were quantified using an Alpha Innotech image system and Alpha View software (ProteinSimple). Each patient's sample at day 28 was normalized as a percent of that patient's own baseline value.

sec.title: Measurement of AÎ² using microimmunoelectrodes
sec.p: APP/PS1+/â hemizygous mice42 were bred to WT C3H/B6 mice (The Jackson Laboratory) and the APP/PS1+/â offspring were used for experiments at 12 months of age. Male and female littermate mice were distributed between experimental groups.

MIEs, which can measure AÎ² every 60 seconds for up to 3 hours, were prepared similar to previously described methods.40 Carbon fiber microelectrodes were used as the platform sensor due to their high signalâtoânoise ratio, biological compatibility, and miniature size,87 and ability to sensitively detect tyrosine oxidation (66). Electrodes were coated with antibodies specific for AÎ² monomer (HJ2)40 or for oligomers (A11)41 and inserted into the hippocampus to measure brain ISF AÎ² levels or into lateral ventricles to measure CSF AÎ² levels.

Electrodes were preâcalibrated in vitro (see supporting information). In addition to the MIE, a stainlessâsteel bone screw used as a counter electrode and an Ag/AgCl reference electrode (InVivo Metrics) were implanted into the brains of 12âmonthâold APP/PS1+/â transgenic mice. All electrodes were stereotaxically implanted under isofluorane anesthesia. Mice were placed on a heating pad to maintain body temperature and repetitive SWV scans were run every 60 seconds for up to 180Â minutes using a CH Instruments 830D Electrochemical Analyzer with PicoAmp booster. The stereotax was enclosed in a faraday cage to reduce electrical noise. CT1812 or vehicle were administered intravenously via tail vein injection at the concentrations noted. All procedures were approved by the Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee at Washington University, St. Louis, and were in compliance with the Office of Laboratory Animals Welfare and the Guide for the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals, Eighth Edition.
More detail can be found in the supporting information section.

sec.title: Behavioral studies
sec.p: All procedures were approved by the Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee at Stanford University and were in compliance with the Office of Laboratory Animal Welfare and the Guide for the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals, Eighth Edition. Testing of male transgenic Thy1 huAPPSwe/Lnd+ mice in the Morris water maze, YâMaze, or fear conditioning tasks was done according to published methods.45, 46 Studies were designed with four arms: WT, vehicle treated (nÂ =Â 12); WT, CT1812 treated (nÂ =Â 12); transgenic, vehicle treated (nÂ =Â 12); transgenic, CT1812 treated (nÂ =Â 13). All procedures were approved by the Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee at Stanford University and were in compliance with the Office of Laboratory Animals Welfare and the Guide for the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals, Eighth Edition.

To measure brain concentration of drugs, brains were homogenized in 1Â mL PBS per gram of brain tissue using a handheld homogenizer. Brain homogenate was then extracted with three volumes of iceâcold methanol on ice for 15 minutes and centrifuged for 15Â minutes. The supernates were analyzed by LCâMS/MS. Samples were compared to a calibration curve prepared in a similar manner by spiking blank control homogenate with standards prepared in DMSO and then extracted as above.

sec.title: Clinical trial of CT1812 in mildâtoâmoderate AD patients
sec.p: The clinical trial was performed at six sites in Australia and administered by Neuroscience Trials Australia. The study protocol was approved by the Human Research Ethics Committee at the Alfred Hospital, Melbourne, Australia, and was conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and Good Clinical Practice guidelines. All subjects provided written informed consent before participating. Mild to moderate (MMSE 18â26) AD patients (NÂ =Â 19) were randomized to one of three doses of CT1812 (90, 280, or 560Â mg Q.D.) or placebo given orally once daily for 28 days (4Â weeks) to determine safety and tolerability (COG0102, for full listing of inclusion and exclusion criteria see ClinicalTrials.gov NCT02907567). Exploratory outcomes included CSF protein expression measured at baseline (Day 0) and end of treatment (Day 28). Missing samples (declined or failed spinal taps) and variable CSF sample volumes reduced the number of matched baseline and day 28 patient CSF samples available for subsequent analysis.

sec.title: ELISA measurement of CSF synaptic proteins
sec.p: CSF levels of AÎ²40, AÎ²42, tâtau, and pâtau were measured using the INNOTEST ELISA (Fujirebio, Ghent, Belgium), following the recommendations by the manufacturer. NfL was measured using an ELISA from Uhman Diagnostics. These analyses were conducted by boardâcertified laboratory technicians according to Swedish Board for Accreditation and Conformity Assessment (SWEDAC)âapproved protocols. Neurogranin CSF concentrations were measured using an inâhouse ELISA method based on the Ng2 and Ng22 antibodies, as described previously in detail.88 Concentrations of SNAPâ25 in CSF were measured using immunoprecipitation combined with mass spectrometry (IPâMS) as described previously.89

sec.title: LCâMS/MS measurement of CSF synaptic proteins and phosphorylated tau fragments
sec.p: Synaptotagminâ1 measurements were obtained as part of unbiased LCâMS/MS proteomics analysis of AD patient CSF samples at Caprion Biosciences using published methods.90 Additional unbiased proteomics analyses including an enrichment for phosphoâproteome were performed on CSF samples at Proteome Sciences using the protocols as previously published61, 91 with minor modifications. For statistical analysis of unbiased LCâMSâMS proteomics, a linear mixed model was used. Detailed methods can be found in the supporting information section.
